User’s Guide¶

What choices does a user have?¶

LEAPR has the ability to represent coherent and incoherent thermal neutron scattering, both of which have an elastic and an inelastic component. If you are not familiar with these distinctions, consider visiting Types of Scattering.

Below is a flowchart illustrating options available for data processing in LEAPR. The options are split into four main chunks, corresponding to the coherent/incoherent and elastic/inelastic options. Note that the only processing step that is strictly necessary is the continuous treatment in the beginning, which describes both incoherent elastic and incoherent inelastic. All other processes are optional, can be used to either supplement the incoherent treatment or to represent coherent scattering.

In this discussion, thermal scattering treatment is broken into three main sections: incoherent (which includes elastic and inelastic), coherent elastic, and coherent inelastic. For those interested in the equations being solved and approximations made in each of these cases, please visit Theory. This guide primarily serves to introduce the necessary inputs and where these inputs may be found.

Incoherent (Elastic and Inelastic)¶

Every LEAPR run requires that a continuous, solid-type spectrum be processed. Translational/diffusive and discrete oscillator treatment can also be applied, if desired. These three options and their necessary inputs will be discussed below.

Continuous Treatment¶

The continuous treatment takes in a vibrational frequency spectrum (also called a phonon distribution) and computes a scattering law \(S(\alpha,\beta)\) via the phonon expansion method. This approach makes numerous assumptions, which are outlined in Theory of Incoherent Scattering. The following input parameters are necessary to perform a continuous treatment calculation.

Parameter Name

Symbol

Description

Restriction

Card
Order of phonon
expansion

nphon
Number of terms used in the
phonon expansion sum
(default value 100)

\(>0\)

3.c
Phonon grid
spacing

delta
The phonon distribution will be
provided on a uniform energy
grid, starting at 0. This is the
energy spacing in eV

\(>0\)

11.a
Number of points
in phonon grid

ni
Number of values in the phonon
distribution that will be given

\(>0\)

11.b
Phonon
distribution

rho
Phonon distribution values, given
on an equally-spaced grid of
length ni with spacing delta
All rho values
must be \(>0\)

12
Normalization
for continuous
component

tbeta
Continuous, translational, and
discrete oscillators all have weights
which sum to 1. This is the weight
for the continuous spectrum

\(0<\) tbeta \(\leq1\)

13.a

Translational/Diffusive¶

Parameter Name

Symbol

Description

Restriction

Card
Diffusion
constant

c
The translational term can be
either a free-gas law c = 0.0
or a diffusive law c > 0.0

\(\geq0\)

13.b
Normalization
for translational
component

twt
Continuous, translational, and
discrete oscillators all have weights
which sum to 1. This is the weight
for the translational spectrum

\(0 \leq\) twt \(<1\)

13.c

Discrete Oscillators¶

Parameter Name

Symbol

Description

Restriction

Card
Number of
oscillators

nd
The number of oscillators to be
convolved with the existing scattering
law. If nd = 0 then cards 15 and 16
will not be read

\(\geq0\)

14
Oscillator
energies

bdel
Energy locations of the oscillators
are given here, in eV. There must be
nd values provided

\(\geq0\)

15
Oscillator
weights

adel
Continuous, translational, and
discrete oscillators all have weights
which sum to 1. These are the
weights of each oscillator.
There must be nd values given

\(\geq0\)

16

Coherent Elastic¶

Parameter Name

Symbol

Description

Restriction

Card
Number principal
scattering atoms

npr
The number of principal scattering in
the compound. For water, the principal
scatterer is H, so npr = 2

\(> 0\)

5.c
Coherent elastic
option

iel
LEAPR can process coherent elastic
scattering for selected materials. If
iel is set to 0, no coherent elastic.
calculation will be performed. Else,
the following values correspond to
the given materials:
Integer
between
0 and 6

Material

Structure

Graphite

Hex

2

HCP

HCP

FCC

BCC

(default value 0)
Maximum energy

emax
Energy under which Bragg edges will
be considered. LEAPR will return the
Bragg peaks that lie below emax
(default value 5 eV)

\(> 0\)

N/A

Coherent Inelastic¶

Cold Hyrogen and Deuterium¶

Parameter Name

Symbol

Description

Restriction

Card
Cold Hydrogen
option

ncold
If ncold = 0, then no cold hydrogen
calculation will be performed. Otherwise,
the following values will invoke the
corresponding calculation

0,1,2,3,4

5.e

ncold

Nuclide

Spin

1

Hydrogen

Ortho

2

Para

3

Deuterium

Ortho

4

Para
Number of \(\kappa\)
values

nka
The coherent inelastic calculation
requires that a static structure factor
\(S(\kappa)\) be given. nka is the number of
\(S(\kappa)\) values that will be provided. If
nka = 0 then cards 17.b and 18
(dka and ska) are omitted

\(\geq0\)

17.a
Spacing of \(\kappa\)
values

dka
The structure factor \(S(\kappa)\) is provided on a
uniform \(\kappa\) grid with
spacing dka

\(>0\)

17.b
Pair Correlation
Function

ska
This is the static structure factor. There
should be nka values given which lie on
a \(\kappa\) grid of spacing dka
All values
must be
\(>0\)

18

Skold Approximation¶

Parameter Name

Symbol

Description

Restriction

Card
Coherent
inelastic
flag

nsk
If nsk = 0, then coherent inelastic
scattering will not be approximated using
the Vineyard / Skold methods. If
nsk = 1 the Vineyard approximation
will be used, and if nsk = 2 then
the Skold approximation will be used

0,1,2

5.e
Number of \(\kappa\)
values

nka
The coherent inelastic calculation
requires that a static structure factor
\(S(\kappa)\) be given. nka is the number of
\(S(\kappa)\) values that will be provided. If
nka = 0 then cards 17.b and 18
(dka and ska) are omitted

\(\geq0\)

Spacing of \(\kappa\)
values

dka

uniform \(\kappa\) grid with
spacing dka

\(>0\)
